node.text:
New York City alone throws 1.4 Billion pounds of textiles each year including clothing, belts and shoes. 85% of that ends up in the landfills! (According to the NYC Department of Environmental Conservation)

We partnered with FARFETCH on a new project called Past Life where we highlight how clothes have many lives, so we begin caring for their past and future lives. A project to divert clothes from landfills.

A solution besides consuming less paired with buying less and wearing your clothes for longer can be to donate a piece of clothing via FARFETCH Donate -  a donation program that is part of the broader Positively FARFETCH strategy. 

The items donated will then be redistributed for meaningful use, rather than adding to the abundance of clothing waste.

A project by:
@farfetch x @theslowfactory

Directed by @sophfei
DP @agustinabiasutto
Edited by @wonseungii
AC @_eileeny_
Gaffer @lorenzopacedop
Sound @brauliolin
Hair @skimdo
Makeup @ayatariqmua @toodbeauty
Location @arkhous_bk
Music @collisbrowne

Special thanks to: ❤️

Kimberly Drew @museummammy
Mecca James-Williams @meccajw
Babba Rivera @babba
Maria Alia Al-sadek @mariaalia
Fran Tirado @fransquishco
Céline Semaan @celinecelines
Sophia Li @sophfei

node.text: Haunani K. Trask was a powerful leader who fought for the freedom and justice of the Hawaiien people, affirming the Hawaiian culture, identity and politics by speaking truth to power. We hold her in our hearts as she transitions with the ancestors, and we continue the fight.

node.title: We mourn the loss of legendary Haunani K. Trask

node.text:
Biden is NO climate hero, the Biden administration is supporting the largest tar sand pipeline in the world and the most expensive one estimated at $9B harassing and arresting Indigenous women and groups water protectors violating the treaties and their illegal occupation of their land to build and create new routes through Indigenous territories for the most environmentally toxic and destructive project: Alberta’s Tar Sands.

Repost from @democracynow
•
Thousands gathered for a Treaty People Gathering weekend of action to #StopLine3, which would carry more than 750,000 barrels of tar sands oil a day through Indigenous land and fragile ecosystems and endanger lakes, rivers and wild rice beds. More than 100 water protectors led by Indigenous Anishinaabe women were arrested Monday in northern Minnesota during the largest act of civil disobedience to date to halt the pipeline, which if completed, would be "the largest tar sands pipeline in the world," says Winona LaDuke, an Anishinaabe activist and executive director of @honortheearth. "We have a Canadian corporation coming in here trying to make a buck at the end of the fossil fuels era and run over a bunch of Indigenous people, and we're not having it."

node.title: Biden administration supports Canadian Tar San Illegal Pipeline

node.text:
Sounds of your childhood with @ty_ushka exploring climate justice migration and climate refugees through sound. #worldoceansday Sounds of the waves 🌊

Shout out to @culturestrike “Lead with culture not policy” ❤️

📻 I Really Love this Song is a conceptual digital exhibition and visual mixtape curated by @theslowfactory commissioning twenty artists who are in their own right leading voices contributing in the on-going revolution at the intersection of climate and human rights. Powered with @drinkruna official media partner with @dazed #IReallyLoveThisSong 🌈

First 100 to get their free passes will receive a special gift curated by us 👀 including: 🦺 Special collection available for I Really Love this Song is made in partnership with @versiontomorrow

node.title: I Really Love this Song 🌈 Launching on June 22nd

node.text:
Elgorithm’s ( @elgorithm )
Trauma Relief Fund

As part of the 10 month remember since of the Beirut Explosion, as well as the launch of Elgorithm’a Trauma Relief Fund, we’ve prepared a video on Lebanon’s mental health crisis.

“On August 4th 2020 two explosions erupted in the port of Beirut, Lebanon, which sent shockwaves across the city and beyond — people felt the impact up to 150 miles away, with individuals in neighboring island Cyprus reporting noise and rattling windows.

Lebanese homes, businesses and full city blocks were destroyed while thousands were injured and needed immediate care. Hospitals, which were already overwhelmed due to rising Covid-19 cases, are dealing with mass casualties despite limited resources. According to Al Jazeera, three hospitals were fully destroyed while two were damaged. The death toll is currently at 137 and rising, and 5,000 have been injured.” wrote @celinecelines for @voguemagazine the days following the deadly explosion

The final count of people killed because of this explosion amounts to 207, 300,000 were left homeless, 7,500 were injured.

Prioritizing trauma relief is central in healing our bodies and spirits in order to heal our land and city. Please consider supporting @elgorithm fund for Beirut.

node.text:
📌 Reposting this live between @ahmedeldin and @celinecelines, now with ASL interpretation and captions as promised 🤟❤️
. . .
In this live, the two demystify Free Palestine as a movement anchored in human rights for all, a movement at the end to antisemitism. They answer the age-old question “but Hamas?” and define urbicide: the action of destroying entire cities (Gaza) and the role of the media in the manipulation of truth and censorship.

node.text:
Temporarily saving this Live with @ahmedeldin here on IGTV so we can download it and add close captions & include our ASL interpreters—In this Live @celinecelines & @ahmedeldin demystify Free Palestine as a movement anchored in human rights for all, a movement at the opposite end to Anti-Semitism. We answer the age-old question “but Hamas” and define urbicide: the action of destroying entire cities (Gaza). The role of the Media and the manipulation of truth, censorship. We will be adding subtitles / ASL 

Stay tuned ✌️

#Repost @nowthisnews

LIFE UNDER OCCUPATION: ‘We need this. We need this for the future.’ — Palestinian writer and activist @vivien.sansour is on a mission to save the foods of her childhood that are disappearing under Israeli occupation

#palestine #palestinian #food #seeds #history

node.title: Vivien Sansour is building a Palestinian Heirloom Seed Library

node.text:
Celebrating Earth Day with a partnership with @pinterest x @theslowfactory discussing Peer to peer knowledge — Open Education ✏️ and the power of visual learning and images. Check out our Boards on Pinterest 1) Earth Day Archive 2) Open Education where all of our visual information is available as an open archive for all 🌎

EDUCATION IS THE FOUNDATION OF PROGRESS

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Slow Factory 🌍 on July 19, 2021.

node.text:
[Edited] ICYMI Ben & Jerry’s (@benandjerrys ) announced it will not renew the license agreement with their manufacturer in occupied Palestine. This is a significant victory for the #bds movement and proof that the growing mainstream support for a #FreePalestine is creating change.

❌ HOWEVER, We’re ambivalent about some of the fine print, so we’ll be watching closely to make sure @benandjerrys follows through on the spirit of the commitment. Divesting from the Israeli apartheid regime must be more than performative action couched in technicalities. 🍦

ID: A vintage Ben & Jerry’s ad campaign remixed by the Slow Factory team, instead of the traditional “brownies that do good” it is replaced with “Decolonization never tasted so sweet. It starts with land back” A Palestinian flag is seen on the horizon.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Slow Factory 🌍 on July 18, 2021 tagging @isaaccordal, and @brenttoderian. May be a Twitter screenshot of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Brent Toderian @BrentToderian Life imitating art warning about death. #ClimateCrisis Art, 2014: "Politicians discussing global warming" Reality, 2021'.

node.text:
We had to pop in here, we’ve been away for two weeks — find us on Twitter where we share more information daily! Would love to hear how you’ve all been coping with the avalanche of terrible news regarding climate chaos. 

ID: twitter screenshot from @BrentToderian "Life imitating art warning about death #ClimateCrisis with two similar images. Left: Art 2014: Politicians discussing global warming. Photograph of art by Isaac Cordal @isaaccordal We see perhaps a dozen old white men in a huddle, submerged in water to the shoulders or over their heads. Right: Reality, 2021. News image of recent flooding in Germany showing a group of mostly older white men & women submerged to their torso and neck struggling in a city street.

node.text:
New York City alone throws 1.4 Billion pounds of textiles each year including clothing, belts and shoes. 85% of that ends up in the landfills! (According to the NYC Department of Environmental Conservation)

We partnered with FARFETCH on a new project called Past Life where we highlight how clothes have many lives, so we begin caring for their past and future lives. A project to divert clothes from landfills.

A solution besides consuming less paired with buying less and wearing your clothes for longer can be to donate a piece of clothing via FARFETCH Donate -  a donation program that is part of the broader Positively FARFETCH strategy. 

The items donated will then be redistributed for meaningful use, rather than adding to the abundance of clothing waste.

A project by:
@farfetch x @theslowfactory

Directed by @sophfei
DP @agustinabiasutto
Edited by @wonseungii
AC @_eileeny_
Gaffer @lorenzopacedop
Sound @brauliolin
Hair @skimdo
Makeup @ayatariqmua @toodbeauty
Location @arkhous_bk
Music @collisbrowne

Special thanks to: ❤️

Kimberly Drew @museummammy
Mecca James-Williams @meccajw
Babba Rivera @babba
Maria Alia Al-sadek @mariaalia
Fran Tirado @fransquishco
Céline Semaan @celinecelines
Sophia Li @sophfei

node.text: Haunani K. Trask was a powerful leader who fought for the freedom and justice of the Hawaiien people, affirming the Hawaiian culture, identity and politics by speaking truth to power. We hold her in our hearts as she transitions with the ancestors, and we continue the fight.

node.text:
“Land Back” is not a metaphor—reconciliation must go beyond taking down statues; statues that never should have been erected in the first place celebrating genocide on stolen land. We are in solidarity with Indigenous people here in the Americas and internationally. We believe in the power of education in unlearning harmful colonial capitalist imperialism and in imagining a world we deserve. Slow Factory is a school and a lab where pluralism and decoloniality are explored to research, document and develop new narratives and systems that are built with the people and ecosystems at the center. 

ID: Lisa Simpson in front of a classroom with a board behind her, it reads “Colonization literally changed global temperatures, it started the climate disaster we’re in and the only way to end it is returning the land to its original stewards who took care of it for thousands of years.” via Twitter account: nishgay @anishinaa.gay 

Second slide: Created by @theslowfactory a New York subway sign that reads “Munsee Lenape” LAND BACK http://native-land.ca to find what the Indigenous land you live on is called

node.text:
Microplastics are released into the environment every time a polyester garment is washed in a washing machine, every time someone removes their glitter make-up after a party, every time a bottle of water is crushed under pressure and can’t and won’t be recycled.

There are more microplastics in the ocean than stars in the milky-way. Microplastics are a bi-product of colonial addiction to plastic and oil and the constant marketing ploy to replace it with recycled plastic bottles. That solution contributes to even more harm in accelerating the erosion of coral reefs by emitting 14 million metric tons of microplastics sitting on the seafloor.

Slow Factory is acting as a knowledge partner in looking into the bio-glitter that TooD Makeup @toodbeauty is investing in.

Made from eucalyptus cellulose, packed with natural pigments & designed to biodegrade, BioGlitter is a true revolutionary beauty product. TooD’s glitter is made with pioneering BioGlitter PURE which is plastic-free and certified TÜV Austria—the highest level of independent certification for freshwater biodegradability in the world. BioGlitter breaks down in natural environments in as little as 28 days.

node.accessibility_caption:
Slide 3: Solutions exist that aren’t being funded or prioritized. That’s why we’re supporting these creatives.
Sayo Watanabe - Sayo collects bubble mailer bags and plastic rice bags to create  everyday, lasting accessories out of soft plastics that are currently difficult  to recycle.
Natasha Mays - Natasha is working with waste from her local community to create a shredded-fill alternative for  a puffer jacket. She will  explore the concept of using an overlocker machine cutting waste and  items that would be heading to the landfill , to see  how to create the best shred-material to replace goose/plastic based fills or waddings.
Mary Lempres and Charlotte Böhning - Mary and Charlotte are proposing an alternative to animal-based leathers made of a carbon-sequestering bioplastic fabric that utilizes food and agricultural waste in the form of biochar.
Bob Carswell and Robert Seevers - Bob and Robert collect waste, process it, spin it into new yarn, and make new fabrics and products, including their “circular sweater,” which will be “from waste to wear in 75 miles.
Delfina Farias - Delfina is creating a guide to  help fashion designers utilize modular design as a methodology for creating waste-led design. This guide will incorporate a capsule collection and take on modular design to showcase the application of this system.
Gordon Holliday - Gordon is designing a capsule collection by using deconstruction and reconstruction techniques to remedy fashion waste in the fashion industry.

node.text:
We are excited to announce the cohort of the WM Design Challenge an initiative powered by Slow Factory that looks at waste as a new resource. The regenerative design challenge is based on waste-led design, a methodology Slow Factory as well as the following designers have in common. Supported by WM, the program will fund 6 participants, match them with advisors and provide them with an innovative approach to get their circular ideas to market. This is a 9 month long program where solutions around textile waste, regenerative systems, recycling solutions, waste to material innovations will be designed, produced and launched within this program. Congratulations to the following designers! We cannot wait to follow your journeys!

#wastestudy @wastemanagement 

ID: a carousel of information announcing our new program: WM Design Challenge, the posts are green with white bold fonts. They read:

Waste is a systemic issue — in Nature, the concept of waste does not exist

WM and Slow Factory Foundation have joined forces to support the next generation of fashion designers in applying circular and regenerative principles to their work. 

Slide 2: Thinking in systems is what Slow Factory & WM have in common

Through the WM Design Challenge, selected participants will create original design solutions for products, materials, and/or systems that embrace regenerative practices. Participants will engage in a seven-month challenge that will culminate with their designs and projects being showcased at the 2022 WM Sustainability Forum.
This program will challenge participants to experiment with and provide tangible solutions for disassembly and reuse of products through de-manufacturing, up-cycling materials and other processes. This is the foundation of waste-led design, a term devised by Slow Factory co-founder Colin Vernon. Each participant/team will receive a $1,000 grant to explore and develop functional design solutions. 

Slide 3: Solutions exist that aren’t being funded or prioritized. That’s why we’re supporting these creatives.

ID continues in Alt-Text

node.text:
Waste is a colonial construct—in nature the idea of waste doesn’t exist. Today we will announce a major program funding designers who are working on waste-led design: waste as a new resources with our partners @wastemanagement #wastestudy 

id: A still from our documentary Landfills as Museums, the image is taken inside a van with green construction helmets overlooking one of the biggest landfill near New York City taking up to 1,000 trucks of waste per day. There is a yellow font caption at the bottom of the image, it reads “The idea of waste is a colonial construct”

node.text:
We are always reflecting our role on this platform and how to ensure that our voice is contributing to our community. Giving you a glimpse of what goes on behind the scenes, sharing candid thoughts from our slow team group text. 

Would love to hear your thoughts on the matter 👇 share your views with us ✏️ 

📌 How can we best contribute to your work & community?

ID: Group text iMessage with the Slow Team, the first text says:

Notes on social media:

Slow Factory is not a news outlet, regurgitating the news in a cute design — that is content pollution, the illusion of knowledge and activism.

We are conscious of our role in trauma stewardship, building resilient systems countering oppression and must create a culture that works for our community and our team.

Syntyché responds: always lifelong unlearning!
